title: 109_s3953
content: The Act may be cited as the "Minority Entrepreneurship Development Act of 2006". Congress finds that in 2005, African American and Hispanic American unemployment rates were well above the national average. Minority-owned businesses are crucial for economic development and growth in communities. Between 1987 and 1997, revenue from minority-owned firms increased by 22.5 percent annually, and employment opportunities within these firms rose by 23 percent. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. In this Act, the terms "Administration" and "Administrator" refer to the Small Business Administration and its Administrator. The term "eligible association or organization" includes national minority business associations organized under specific sections of the Internal Revenue Code with a national network of local chapters or national membership. An eligible educational institution must have existed for at least 10 years before receiving a grant under section 6. It includes public or private higher education institutions and historically Black colleges, Hispanic-serving institutions, or tribal colleges. The term "historically Black college" refers to a part B institution under the Higher Education Act of 1965. The term "Hispanic-serving institution" is defined in the Higher Education Act of 1965. The term "institution of higher education" is defined in the Higher Education Act of 1965. The term "small business concern" and "small business development center" are defined in the Small Business Act. The term "tribal college" is defined as a "tribally controlled college or university" under the Tribally Controlled Community College Assistance Act of 1978. SEC. 4. MINORITY SMALL BUSINESS DEVELOPMENT. The Small Business Act is amended to include a new section on minority small business development. The Small Business Act is amended to establish an Office of Minority Small Business Development within the Administration, administered by the Associate Administrator for Minority Small Business Development. The Associate Administrator is responsible for formulating and promoting policies to assist small business concerns owned by minorities. The Office of Minority Small Business Development within the Administration is tasked with increasing minority participation in finance programs and counseling/training. The Office of Minority Small Business Development aims to increase minority participation in entrepreneurial development programs, contracts, and resources through various initiatives and partnerships. The Office of Minority Small Business Development is authorized appropriations of $5,000,000 for fiscal years 2007, 2008, and 2009 to support its programs and objectives. Additionally, there are conforming amendments to the Small Business Act to streamline the focus on Minority Small Business Development. The Minority Entrepreneurship and Innovation Pilot Program of 2006 is established under Section 5. The Administrator may provide grants to eligible educational institutions for establishing an entrepreneurship curriculum and placing a small business development center on campus. The curriculum must include training in business management, marketing, financial management, accounting, market analysis, competitive analysis, innovation, and strategic planning. The curriculum developed under this paragraph focuses on helping non-business majors become entrepreneurs by providing them with the necessary tools. Each eligible educational institution must open a small business development center to support small business concerns through studies, research, and counseling. The small business development center provides management training, technical assistance, referral services, and promotes innovation for small business concerns. Grant awards may not be given to a single eligible educational institution. Funds under this section cannot exceed $1,000,000 in a fiscal year or be used for more than 2 years. They must be used for direct costs related to curriculum development or operating a small business development center, excluding building expenses or unrelated administrative costs. The Small Business Act does not require matching funds for grants under this section. The Associate Administrator must submit an annual report evaluating the program's success to the Senate and House Committees on Small Business. The report must include a description of each entrepreneurship program. Authorization of Appropriation: $24,000,000 for each fiscal year from 2007 to 2009 to fund entrepreneurship programs, small business development centers, and economic impact assessments. The Administrator must use only allocated funds for this purpose. SEC. 6. MINORITY ACCESS TO INFORMATION DISTANCE LEARNING PILOT PROGRAM OF 2006. The Administrator may grant funds to eligible associations and organizations to assist in providing online or distance learning for businesses seeking to contract with the Federal Government, develop curriculum for seminars, and offer training at low or no cost. The curriculum should include training in areas like accounting and marketing for small business owners to successfully contract with the Federal Government. The Administrator may award grants up to $250,000 for a maximum of 2 years to eligible associations or organizations for developing curriculum related to Federal procurement. The funds must be used solely for direct costs associated with curriculum development. The Administrator may award grants up to $250,000 for curriculum development related to Federal procurement. The funds must be used solely for direct costs. Matching requirements do not apply to grants under this section. An annual report evaluating program success must be submitted to specific committees. Each report shall describe distance learning programs developed with grant funds, including the number of participants and economic impact. $4,000,000 is authorized for fiscal years 2007-2009. The Administrator must only use appropriated funds for this section. SEC. 7 of the Federal Acquisition Streamlining Act of 1994 is amended to extend the socially and economically disadvantaged business program until September 30, 2009. The effective date of this amendment will be 30 days after the enactment of the Act.
